title: How to Find the Weight of an Object Without a Scale

methods.name: Finding the Weight Through the Volume

steps.headline: Figure out the volume of the object.
steps.description: Let's say you have a cube with a dimension of 10x10x10. The volume would be 1000.

steps.headline: Use the formula mass equals density times volume.
steps.description: This requires you to know the density of the object. If the object is water, for example, you know it has a density of 1 gram per cubic centimetres. So for a volume of water of 1000 cc, the weight is 1000 grams.

steps.headline: Know the density of different matters:Gold - 19.32
steps.description: Lead - 11.3437 Silver - 10.5020 Copper - 8.5 to 8.8 Steel - 7.9 Iron - 7.4 to 7.7 Aluminium - 2.7 Limestone 2.6 to 2.8 Glass - 2.4 to 2.8 Brick - 1.4 to 2.2 Concrete - 2.2 to 2.5 Ice - 0.9 Wax - 0.9 Pinewood - 0.5 Mercury - 13.543 Seawater - 1.03 Water - 1.0 Petrol - 0.85

methods.name: Finding the Weight Through the Force Exerted

steps.headline: Figure out the mass through the force exerted.
steps.description: Do this by dividing the acceleration by the force exerted (by Newton's second law: force equals mass times acceleration). For example, if a cube has an acceleration of 1000 millimetres per second squared (always measure in millimetres) and the force exerted is 2 kilograms millimetres per second squared, then the cube must weigh 2 grams.

methods.name: Finding the Weight with a Handmade Balance

steps.headline: Balance a balance with lightweight, identical cups at both ends.
steps.description: This can be a ruler balanced on an object, or a string over something with little friction with cups tied at both ends.

steps.headline: Place the object at one end, and fill the other cup with pure water until it balances with the object.
steps.description: If the object is too light to find the weight this way, you'll need to either decrease the friction at the pulley or at the fulcrum, or use lighter-weight materials for the balance and cups.

steps.headline: Measure the volume of the matching water, and convert to milliliters.
steps.description: The volume in milliliters is the same as the weight in grams.

So for a volume of water of 1000 cc, the weight is 1000 grams.
